review: I'm not a huge fan of chromecast.  For what it does it's pretty cool, but it wasn't worth spending the money for me.  I am more of a fan of Apple TV or ROKU than Chromecast.  I have a cable that allows me to hook my MacBook up to my TV and do everything that Chromecast does, without the lag.  With chromecast you have to have some sort of compatible device to link to it and then from there it streams to your TV.  The lag is pretty bad and the setting up was more of hassle than the benefit that I saw in it.  Like I said the cable that I have allows me to hook my MacBook up to my TV and do everything that Chromecast can do and more at a fraction of the price.  If you're looking for a device to hook up to your TV and keep there permanently I would highly recommend an Apple TV or Roku, read more about them and decide which one is better for you.

review: Great product! Very impressed with easy installation. Love to "cast" movies from our Android supporting devices.Depending on which high-speed internet provider (and movie streaming service) you use, you may experience faster streamed movies = much higher resolution streamed movie quality, For example, in our home when we do NOT use the Chromecast, then Comcast "throttles back" the streaming rate for Netflix down below 0.8 MB/sec (horrible!) when we use any one of my other media players (Apple TV, Western Digital HD Media Player, or Sony Sony BDP-S580 Blu-ray Disc Player). (Comcast is a horrible high-speed internet provider)However, if I stream Netflix directly through the Chromecast, the streaming rate and resulting movie resolution is MUCH higher. This makes sense because Comcast wouldn't dare throttle all streaming and web surfing done directly through any PC or smartphone appearing device. You see, it is not so easy for Comcast to determine IF you are streaming Netflix through a pc/tablet/smartphone, but Comcast can tell based on IP if you're streaming Netflex through many set-top-box style media streaming players
